intro: Tapinanthus sapinii, commonly known as the parasitic milkweed, is a hemiparasitic plant that relies on host plants for some of its nutritional needs. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its lack of chlorophyll, which means it cannot perform photosynthesis. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a fibrous root system that attaches to the roots of its host. It is typically found in arid and semi-arid regions, often growing on the roots of trees and shrubs. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have a significant impact on the growth and survival of its host plants.
